author: @business_today
title: 39% of skills outdated by 2030: WEF warns of AI's impact on jobs
text:
Artificial intelligence is reshaping the global job market, and the changes are coming faster than expected. According to the World Economic Forum (WEF), half of all employers plan to reorient their businesses in response to AI, while two-thirds aim to hire talent with AI-specific skills. At the same time, 40% anticipate reducing their workforce in roles where automation can take over.
The WEF‚Äôs Future of Jobs Report 2025, based on input from over 1,000 employers across 55 economies, predicts significant job creation alongside massive displacement. Over the next five years, clerical and secretarial roles will face the steepest declines, with positions like admin assistants, ticket clerks, and cashiers increasingly replaced by AI-driven tools and automation.
On the brighter side, industries requiring human oversight and hands-on expertise are expected to grow. Roles in delivery, construction, food processing, and farming are among those set to expand. The care economy‚Äîincluding nursing, social work, and personal care‚Äîwill also see strong growth due to the irreplaceable human touch required in these professions.
For workers, skill adaptation will be critical. The report warns that 39% of existing skill sets will become outdated by 2030. While this figure marks an improvement from the pandemic‚Äôs peak of 57%, it underscores the urgency of upskilling in AI, big data, and software development. IT specialists in robotics, autonomous systems, and renewable energy technologies are forecast to thrive in this evolving landscape.
The report also highlights broader trends influencing job markets. Rising costs of living could eliminate 1.6 million jobs, although respondents believe many will be replaced. Trade restrictions and economic challenges will add to the pressures reshaping global labor markets.
Between job displacement and creation, the WEF estimates a net growth of 78 million jobs by 2030, signaling that adaptability will define future workforce success.

author: ldombro
title: 7 Women's March Madness stars ready to take vacant spotlight from Caitlin Clark
text:
Who will steal the show in this year's Women's NCAA Tournament like Caitlin Clark did in years past? By Levi Dombro |
Share on Facebook
Share on X
Copy Article
UCLA v USC | Andy Lyons/GettyImages Caitlin Clark was the biggest star in college basketball for several seasons with the Iowa Hawkeyes. She parlayed that into being the top draft choice in the 2024 WNBA Draft, and her stardom reached new heights at the professional level.
However, a massive chasm was left in the women's college game after she left, and several stars will be vying to be the biggest name in March Madness this year. The country is full of amazing talent this season, but there are only a handful of players who are ready for the spotlight in the NCAA Tournament when the lights are brightest.
7. Lauren Betts, C, UCLA Betts has been a force for the Bruins all season on both ends of the floor. UCLA only lost two games this season, both of them to their bitter rival USC, but they avenged those losses by taking down the Trojans in the Big Ten Tournament Championship. The Bruins are the No. 1 overall seed and there might not be a team in the country playing better than they are right now. If they make a big tournament run, Betts will almost certainly be leading the charge and could steal the show this March.
6. Hannah Hidalgo, G, Notre Dame Hidalgo was the front-runner for the National Player of the Year Award for a good portion of the year until a late-season slide. She still has the capability to be the best player in the tournament, and she'll be coming in with quite a chip on her shoulder. She is one of the best scorers in the country and should be the focal point for a Notre Dame team that is poised to make a deep run, which means she could be poised for stardom in the tournament.
5. Hailey Van Lith, G, TCU Van Lith has something to prove this year after a lackluster performance for LSU last season. Now the star of the TCU Horned Frogs and the Big 12 Conference Player of the Year, she'll be more than ready to lead her team on a deep tournament run, and to do it in electrifying fashion. Watching her play the game is just enjoyable, and she has a rematch with Louisville, her old school, potentially waiting for her in the second round of the tournament. Van Lith will be must-see TV in March Madness.
4. Paige Bueckers, G, UConn Bueckers fell on hard times at points during her college career but is still one of the best players in women's college basketball of the last decade. She and the UConn Huskies are playing their best basketball right now, and Bueckers is leading the charge, which positions her nicely for a share of the spotlight in the Big Dance.
3. Ta'Niya Latson, G, Florida State Ta'Niya Latson is the country's leading scorer at 24.9 points per contest and should turn some heads in the NCAA Tournament. She and the Florida State Seminoles are just a No. 6 seed, but they could be the exact kind of Cinderella team that March Madness needs this year. If they can win in the first round, they'll have a series of high-profile matchups looming against LSU, NC State and UCLA, which should cast quite a bit of attention on Latson and her scoring prowess.
2. Mikayla Blakes, G, Vanderbilt Blakes is already one of the nation's best scorers as a true freshman for the Vanderbilt Commodores. She averaged 23.2 points per game in a loaded SEC this season and proved that no moment is too big for her. Vanderbilt will have an uphill battle this March as a No. 7 seed, but if they can pull off a handful of upsets, Blakes may walk out of the tournament as a household name.
1. Juju Watkins, G, USC Watkins is the obvious heir to the Caitlin Clark throne. She is the frontrunner for the National Player of the Year Award and is poised to lead the USC Trojans on a deep tournament run. She can do everything on the basketball court and is the most exciting player to watch in all of college basketball. If her team can avoid early upsets, she will be the talk of the tournament, undoubtedly.

author: Bdaily Business News
title: Newcastle engineering firm creates jobs to bolster growth plans throughout 2024
text: Newcastle engineering firm creates jobs to bolster growth plans throughout 2024 Business performance in the civil and structural engineering sector will remain resilient with green shoots starting to show in the residential market, said Ross Oakley, managing director of Newcastle engineers RWO. This will drive additional growth and expansion over the next 12 months for North East engineers such as RWO, with a steady stream of work coming up in the year ahead as previously delayed projects get the green light. Ross Oakley also expects to see increasing volumes of work for geo-environmental engineering services as activity remains ‚Äòextremely‚Äô busy in the sector with a plethora of new projects coming forward in the new year. Civil engineering work could see an industry predicted 17 per cent rise in starts in the next 12 months, an achievable figure, Ross Oakley believes, whose firm will see increased levels of work for social housing providers, and a growing footprint in burgeoning data centre design and build. Ross commented: ‚ÄúWe are looking forward to cautious growth in 2024, driven by a strengthening in work across almost all sectors and rescheduled projects getting underway. New investment in utilities, energy and telecoms infrastructure will be to fore in the coming months, powering growth in demand for services like ours.‚Äù RWO is targeting revenues in excess of ¬£3m in the next 12 months as it looks towards another strong performance in 2025 with plans for further investment in its workforce helping to drive growth, said managing director Ross Oakley. He added: ‚ÄúWe are recruiting to fuel planned growth in the coming 18 months as further new customers come onboard. We are committed to getting the right people and offering an excellent employee benefits package which includes training and opportunities for career development.‚Äù By [Matthew Neville](https://bdaily.co.uk/profile/matthew-bdaily) ‚Äì Senior Correspondent, Bdaily - Add me on - And follow Bdaily on - Submit press releases to [editor@bdaily.co.uk](mailto:editor@bdaily.co.uk)for consideration. Looking to promote your product/service to SME businesses in your region? [ Find out how Bdaily can help ‚Üí ](https://marketing.bdaily.co.uk) Enjoy the read? Get Bdaily delivered. Sign up to receive our popular North East morning email for free.

author: Decatur Daily Democrat
title: Mavemall Revolutionizes the iPad Experience with the Long-standing Swift 360 Keyboard Case | News | decaturdailydemocrat.com
text: Swift 360 Keyboard by MaveMall, a prominent name in the technology accessories industry, continues to rank amongst the best iPad keyboards in the world even years after its launch. Swift 360 Keyboard is a revolutionary product set to redefine standards in the iPad accessory domain. The widely popular keyboard brings unprecedented functionality, converting the iPad into an exceptionally versatile device. Amidst a competitive market, Swift 360 distinguishes itself with a distinctive blend of features and design. Setting it apart from counterparts like the Apple Magic Keyboard and Logitech Combo Touch, the Swift 360 Keyboard boasts its own built-in battery, guaranteeing consistent performance and greater efficiency. It also features adjustable backlit keys available in seven colors, providing adaptability for users in different lighting environments. A significant advantage of the Swift 360 Keyboard is its built-in battery, offering independence from the iPad's power and thus extended usability, a feature that Apple's and Logitech's models lack as they draw power directly from the iPad. Furthermore, the Swift 360 enhances user experience with its customizable backlit keys, offering seven color options to suit various preferences and lighting conditions, a level of personalization not found in the relatively static backlighting of the other two. The Apple Magic Keyboard is known for its unique floating design, and the Logitech Combo Touch has a keyboard you can detach and a stand you can adjust. However, the Swift 360 is special because it can rotate fully, giving users more ways to view and use it. This makes the Swift 360 more than just a keyboard; it's a versatile tool that improves how lots of different people use their iPads. Additions like the integrated Apple Pencil holder and extensive iPad protection highlight the keyboard's considerate and comprehensive design approach. Founded in 2021, MaveMall quickly expanded from a small home office into a successful online store with customers worldwide. "The Swift 360 represents the pinnacle of our intensive research and our commitment to crafting products that truly enhance the lives of our customers. Our growth shows our dedication to keep creating quality products," said Nick from MaveMall. As a company deeply committed to its customers, MaveMall continues to seek creative ways to enhance its offerings. "We're not just selling products; we're enriching experiences," Nick added. Join the revolution and elevate your iPad experience with MaveMall's latest innovation. The Swift 360 Keyboard is available for purchase. https://themavemall.com/collections/ipad-cases/products/rotatable-ipad-keyboard-case Media Contact Company Name: MaveMall Contact Person: Nick Email: Send Email City: London Country: United Kingdom Website: themavemall.com/

author: Johanna Ewald
title: Richterwahl bei ‚ÄûMarkus Lanz": Ha√üelmann wirft CDU Versagen vor
text:
Berlin. Die Gr√ºnen-Fraktionschefin kritisiert bei Markus Lanz die CDU f√ºr das Debakel um Frauke Brosius-Gersdorf ‚Äì war es Spahns F√ºhrungsversagen?
‚ÄûAm Tag danach ‚Äì einem denkw√ºrdigen Gespr√§ch‚Äú: So er√∂ffnet Markus Lanz am Mittwochabend seine Sendung ‚Äì mit Verweis auf den emotionalen Auftritt von Frauke Brosius-Gersdorf am Vorabend. Die SPD-Kandidatin f√ºr das Bundesverfassungsgericht steht im Zentrum einer Debatte, die l√§ngst zum politischen Beben geworden ist.
Die G√§ste bei ‚ÄûMarkus Lanz‚Äú am 16. Juli
- Britta Ha√üelmann, Gr√ºnen-Politikerin
- Christoph Plo√ü, CDU-Politiker
- Melanie Amann, Journalistin
- Robin Alexander, Journalist
Gr√ºnen-Fraktionschefin Britta Ha√üelmann benennt klar, wer aus ihrer Sicht das politische Desaster verursacht hat: ‚ÄûEin eklatantes F√ºhrungsversagen von Jens Spahn.‚Äú Der CDU-Politiker habe seine Fraktion nicht vorbereitet und die Kandidatin im Regen stehen lassen. Den Plagiatsvorwurf gegen Brosius-Gersdorf nennt sie eine ‚ÄûHilfskonstruktion‚Äú, die ‚Äûwie ein Kartenhaus zusammengefallen‚Äú sei.
Auch interessant
Auch Moderator Lanz merkt an, dass von 24 zur Sendung eingeladenen CDU-Vertreterinnen und Vertretern nur Christoph Plo√ü zugesagt hat. ‚ÄûDass hier niemand der F√ºhrung der CDU sitzt, spricht f√ºr sich‚Äú, kommentiert ‚ÄûWelt‚Äú-Vize Robin Alexander.
Robin Alexander bei ‚ÄûMarkus Lanz‚Äú: CDU hat Kontrolle √ºber Fraktion verloren
Alexander bewertet die Lage als Fiasko: Die CDU-F√ºhrung habe ‚Äûdie Kontrolle √ºber ihre eigene Fraktion verloren‚Äú. Dass ausgerechnet Merz und Spahn, die Angela Merkel einst mangelnden Zugang zur Partei vorwarfen, nun selbst die Dynamiken nicht im Griff h√§tten, sei ‚Äûironisch‚Äú. Sein Fazit: ‚ÄûDer Skandal ist der Umgang damit, nicht die Zweifel an der Kandidatin.‚Äú
Der CDU-Abgeordnete Christoph Plo√ü rechtfertigt den R√ºckzug der Union: ‚ÄûIch h√§tte sie auch nicht gew√§hlt.‚Äú Er betont mehrfach den Schutz der Menschenw√ºrde ‚Äì vor allem des ungeborenen Lebens. Als Beleg zitiert er, sichtlich vorbereitet ‚Äì er holt einen Zettel aus der Brusttasche ‚Äì, einen isolierten Satz aus Brosius-Gersdorfs Stellungnahme: ‚ÄûEs gibt gute Gr√ºnde daf√ºr, dass die Menschenw√ºrdegarantie erst ab Geburt gilt.‚Äú
Auch interessant
Lanz reagiert scharf: ‚ÄûDann lesen Sie bitte auch den zweiten, dritten und vierten Satz vor.‚Äú Denn genau dieser Satz ist einer der Aufh√§nger f√ºr viele verzerrte Darstellungen, die die Juristin als Aktivistin framen. Auch Amann widerspricht: ‚ÄûSie kommt nicht als Aktivistin an das Verfassungsgericht. Das ist eine exzellente Juristin.‚Äú Alexander erg√§nzt: ‚ÄûDass der Abtreibungskompromiss intellektuell an Grenzen st√∂√üt, war schon immer so.‚Äú
Frauenfeindliche Dynamiken im politischen Betrieb
Amann betont, dass Brosius-Gersdorf das Spannungsfeld zwischen dem Schutz des ungeborenen Lebens und dem Recht der Frau differenziert dargestellt habe. Doch die Debatte eskaliert ‚Äì auch auf metapolitischer Ebene. ‚ÄûJetzt m√∂chte ich mal zu Ende reden‚Äú, sagt Amann mehrfach, nachdem ihr die m√§nnlichen G√§ste ins Wort gefallen sind. Sie stellt klar: ‚ÄûIch m√∂chte den Eindruck zerstreuen, dass es hier nur um Inhalte ging.‚Äú
Ha√üelmann bringt die strukturelle Dimension auf den Punkt: ‚ÄûIch habe kein Interesse mehr daran, dass M√§nner mir die Welt erkl√§ren.‚Äú Sie verurteilt die ‚Äûb√∂swilligen Unterstellungen‚Äú, Brosius-Gersdorf bef√ºrworte Sp√§tabtreibungen einen Tag vor der Geburt ‚Äì ein Narrativ, das √∂ffentlich lanciert wurde. Au√üerdem verweist sie auf einen vergleichbaren Umgang mit Margaretha Sudhof, der Sonderermittlerin zur Maskenaff√§re.
¬ß218-Debatte verdeckt das politische Problem
Lanz beschreibt Brosius-Gersdorfs Auftritt als mutig: ‚ÄûSie hat das gegen den Rat aller um sie herum gemacht. Das ist etwas, was eine Frau macht, die sich ihr Leben zur√ºckholen will.‚Äú Amann hebt hervor: ‚ÄûMan hat ihr die Anspannung in den ersten Minuten angemerkt.‚Äú Sie fragt sich jedoch, wie viele Zuschauende der juristischen Komplexit√§t folgen konnten. F√ºr Amann ist klar: ‚ÄûKarlsruhe ist damit f√ºr sie in weite Ferne ger√ºckt.‚Äú
Wieder und wieder dreht sich die Diskussion um Paragraph 218, der unter anderem den Umgang mit Abtreibungen regelt. Ha√üelmann reicht es irgendwann: ‚ÄûVielleicht muss man einfach mal sagen: Cut. Wir f√ºhren hier doch keine ¬ß218-Debatte, sondern sprechen √ºber das Scheitern einer Wahl zum h√∂chsten Gericht.‚Äú Die Gr√ºnen-Politikerin warnt: Das Muster erinnere an Strategien der AfD ‚Äì und die Union lasse sich treiben. ‚ÄûIch mache mir gro√üe Sorgen um CDU und CSU.‚Äú
Brosius-Gersdorfs Karriere wohl beendet ‚Äì Politik bleibt Antworten schuldig
Amann stellt grunds√§tzlich infrage, ob das bisherige Verfahren zur Richterwahl noch funktioniert: ‚ÄûIch glaube, wir haben jetzt die letzte normale Bundesverfassungsrichterwahl erlebt.‚Äú Zu undurchsichtig, zu politisiert sei das Verfahren. Ha√üelmann fordert: ‚ÄûDie Koalition muss zeigen, ob sie handlungsf√§hig ist.‚Äú Bislang habe es keinerlei Gespr√§che zwischen den Fraktionen gegeben habe, wie es nun weitergehen soll. ‚ÄûWollen wir die B√ºrgerinnen und B√ºrger im Unklaren lassen, ob die Koalition stabil ist?‚Äú, fragt sie.
Trotz demonstrativer R√ºckendeckung: F√ºr Brosius-Gersdorf steht die T√ºr nach Karlsruhe offenbar kaum noch offen. ‚ÄûAus meiner Sicht spricht viel daf√ºr, dass sie nicht Verfassungsrichterin wird‚Äú, sagt Amann. Die Sendung endet ohne L√∂sung, aber mit einem un√ºbersehbaren Befund: Diese Republik tut sich schwer mit Frauen in Machtpositionen ‚Äì vor allem, wenn sie komplex argumentieren und f√ºr etwas einstehen.
